did.unittitle: Poster collection
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: COLLECTION STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF: Open for research. Advance notice required for access. Contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection assembled by the staff of UCLA Library Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Poster Collection (Collection 95). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of an assemblage of posters, primarily 20th century American and European. Includes travel posters, exhibit posters, and war posters from World War I France, and American posters from World War I and World War II.

did.unittitle: Les Alsaciens et les Lorrains sont Français! [text blocks]. Paris : J. Cussac, Imp., [1914].

scopecontent.p: Signed in lower right of image: "L. Jonas". At lower left: "VISA No. 11.922". Alsace and Lorraine were lost to Germany in the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71 (from LC record). Block of text below image is regarding the history of the Alscae-Lorraine region and its association to the rest of France. LC has this poster and alternate version with different title and text block but same image. Date from LC record.

scopecontent.p: Picket signs read: "Nous voulons / Le lait de Maman / Les soins de Maman / Des sages-femmes competents / Des parents sain / Etre proteges des mouches / Des couches seches / Dormir seuls / Etre nourris regulierement / De l'air et du soleil / Qu'o[n] nous laisse tranquilles / Vivre en bonnes sante." did.unittitle: Barrie's Sentimental Tommy, in Scribner's [New York?, ].

did.unittitle: World War I--France.
France toujours! / France quand même! / Car la France est eternelle, et rien de ce qui est la France ne saurait périr. [S.l.] : Demoulin Frères. SC., [19--] (Paris : Editions Delandre).

scopecontent.p: English translation of title: "France always! France through it all! For France is eternal and could never perish." With accompanying black and white numbered image key (separate sheet, dimensions: 32.5 x 50 cm). Signed in lower left of image: "G. FRAIPONT". Printer device in lower left: quill and a sword forming an 'x' in back of a pot of fire. Below image in center: "deposé".

did.unittitle: Pour le drapeau! Pour la victoire! / Souscrivez á l'Emprunt National / Les Souscriptions sont reçues à Paris et en Province à la Banque National de Crédit. [Paris? : s.n.], 1917 (Paris : Devambez Imp.).

scopecontent.p: English translation of title: "For the flag! For victory! Subscribe to the National Loan." Signed in lower right of image: : "GEORGES SCOTT 1917". Stamp in lower left of image: "3ème Emprunt National / Affiche editée par la Banque National de Crédit". In lower right of image: "VISA_No. 9.498". Handwritten on back: "Scott 3em".

A special national day for the benefit of veterans who were suffering from tuberculosis (from LC record). Date from LC record.

did.unittitle: La journée du Poilu. Paris : I. Lapina. Imp. Edit., 1915.

scopecontent.p: Medallions on both sides of title. Left one reads: 25 Décembre 26 Décembre 1915 Le Poilu. Right one has image of a soldier head in profile (Poilu?) in front of a female statue head in profile with the words 'Le Poilu' underneath. Under title in center of image is a close-up of a notecard which presumably came with the package the soldier in the image is opening. It reads: "Avec vous et par vous nous jourons de sauver la France. Leon Gambetta." Signed in lower right of image: "L. Jonas". Léon Gambetta (1838-1882) was one of the founders of the Third Republic and was regarded as one of the heroes of the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-71. He became premier of France for a short while in 1881 (from LC record).

scopecontent.p: Signed in lower right of image, under soldier's foot: "Maurice Neumont 1918". In lower left next to printer: "VISA No. 13.037". Poison gas was first used in WWI. did.unittitle: "One swine too many..." / The Nazis in Holland tried to spread the idea that slaughtering unweaned calves would leave more milk for dutch children. [Netherlands? : s.n., 1945?].

did.unittitle: Ours...to fight for / Freedom from fear. Washington, D.C. : Office of War Information, 1943 (Washington, D.C. : U.S. Government Printing Office).

scopecontent.p: Signed in lower left of image: "NORMAN ROCKWELL." Image caption: "Painting from the Saturday Evening Post." At bottom: "OWI Poster No.46 / 1943--O-511887." One of four images interpreting the four freedoms enumerated in FDR's Jan. 1941 congressional address and outlined in the Atlantic Charter issued by FDR and Churchill in Aug. 1941. Artist used his Vermont neighbors as models (Bird and Rubenstein, 37).
